cost_objection.objection: The inspection costs $400-600, which seems expensive on top of everything else
cost_objection.wrong_approach: It's worth it for peace of mind / You can't afford not to
cost_objection.authentic_approach: I understand - you're already spending on appraisal, closing costs, and down payment. Here's the reality: the average inspection finds $5,000-$14,000 in issues that become negotiating points. Last month, we found foundation issues in a $350,000 home that saved our client $18,000 in repairs. The inspection pays for itself many times over, and more importantly, it prevents you from buying a house with hidden problems that could cost tens of thousands. What's your biggest concern about the property?
cost_objection.reframe: Investment protection, not expense - the cheapest insurance policy you'll ever buy

trust_seller_objection.objection: The seller seems honest and says everything works fine
trust_seller_objection.wrong_approach: Sellers always lie / You can't trust anyone
trust_seller_objection.authentic_approach: Most sellers are honest about what they know - but that's the key phrase: what they KNOW. Many issues are hidden behind walls, in crawlspaces, or in systems the seller never uses. We regularly find problems in homes where sellers had no idea anything was wrong. Plus, sellers often haven't lived through a full seasonal cycle to know if the HVAC handles summer heat or winter cold. An inspection isn't about catching someone in a lie - it's about discovering what nobody knows yet
trust_seller_objection.reframe: Unknown unknowns vs. seller honesty - even honest sellers don't know everything

new_construction_objection.objection: It's new construction with a builder warranty, so I don't need an inspection
new_construction_objection.wrong_approach: Builders are incompetent / New homes are full of problems
new_construction_objection.authentic_approach: Builder warranties are valuable, but here's what most buyers don't realize: warranties have specific exclusion periods and you need to document issues BEFORE you close. We consistently find installation errors, code violations, and incomplete work in new construction - things like missing insulation, improper grading that will cause water intrusion, HVAC systems incorrectly sized. Once you close, proving these existed before closing becomes your burden. A pre-closing inspection creates documentation that protects your warranty claims and catches issues while the builder is still motivated to fix them
new_construction_objection.reframe: Warranty protection tool, not distrust of builder - document everything before you own it

agent_pressure_objection.objection: My agent says inspections aren't necessary in this market / will kill my offer
agent_pressure_objection.wrong_approach: Your agent doesn't care about you / Agents are corrupt
agent_pressure_objection.authentic_approach: Your agent wants you to get the house, which is their job. But here's the distinction: in competitive markets, you can still inspect - you just might choose an 'inspection for information only' rather than 'inspection contingency.' This means you inspect to know what you're buying, but don't reserve the right to renegotiate. You still get the crucial information to make an informed decision and can walk away if something catastrophic appears. Even in the hottest markets, smart buyers inspect - they just adjust their contract terms. Would you buy a used car without looking under the hood, even if other buyers were willing to?
agent_pressure_objection.reframe: Information vs. contingency - you can still know what you're buying without threatening the deal

timing_objection.objection: I'm not ready to schedule yet / Want to wait until closer to closing
timing_objection.wrong_approach: You're making a mistake / You'll regret this
timing_objection.authentic_approach: I understand wanting to wait, but here's the challenge: if we inspect close to your contingency deadline and find significant issues, you'll have almost no time to get specialist inspections, contractor estimates, or negotiate repairs. Clients who schedule early have time to make informed decisions without panic. Plus, if the inspection reveals a deal-breaker, you want to discover that sooner rather than after you've invested more time and emotion. What's driving the desire to wait - is there something specific you're concerned about?
timing_objection.reframe: Time to respond vs. time to schedule - early inspection creates options, late inspection creates pressure

diy_objection.objection: I'm pretty handy / My friend is a contractor and can look at it
diy_objection.wrong_approach: You don't know what you're doing / Your friend isn't qualified
diy_objection.authentic_approach: Having construction knowledge is valuable, and your friend's input matters. But here's what a professional inspection provides: systematic evaluation of 400+ components, thermal imaging to see inside walls, moisture meters to detect hidden water damage, electrical testing equipment, and most importantly - a written report that gives you legal documentation and negotiating leverage. Your friend doing a favor won't crawl in the attic in July or under the crawlspace in mud. They also won't provide the detailed report your lender might require or that protects you legally. Think of it this way: even doctors don't treat their own family - having an objective, documented professional assessment protects everyone
diy_objection.reframe: Documentation and systematic process vs. casual walkthrough - legal protection requires professional verification

already_inspected_objection.objection: The seller already had a pre-listing inspection
already_inspected_objection.wrong_approach: That inspection is worthless / They're hiding something
already_inspected_objection.authentic_approach: Pre-listing inspections are helpful and show the seller is being proactive. However, that inspector was hired by and worked for the seller - their job was to help the seller prepare the home for sale. Your inspection works for YOU and your interests. Additionally, conditions change - what was fine two months ago might have deteriorated, or the seller might have made repairs that created new issues. Most importantly, you want YOUR inspector who will answer YOUR questions and advocate for YOUR interests. The seller's inspection is useful information, but it doesn't replace your independent verification
already_inspected_objection.reframe: Seller's advocate vs. your advocate - you need someone working for your interests

thread_structure: Winter is coming. Your home inspection checklist just changed. 7 things I'm seeing RIGHT NOW that'll cost you thousands if ignored:

6/ Roof flashing around vents/chimneys. Small gaps = major leaks when snow melts.
7/ Sump pump testing. Frozen ground = spring flooding. Make sure it works BEFORE you need it.
I'm doing pre-winter inspections all month. DM me if you want to avoid a costly surprise.

- Crawlspace (where major issues hide)
- Attic insulation/ventilation
- Detailed electrical panel check
- Thorough roof inspection

Found:
- Active termite damage
- Knob & tube wiring (fire hazard)
- Foundation settling
- Roof needs replacement

That $200 'savings' almost cost them $68K.

What you're paying for with a quality inspector:
- Proper insurance/licensing
- Years of experience
- Detailed reports with photos
- Time to check EVERYTHING
A good inspection is the cheapest insurance policy you'll ever buy.

Questions to ask before hiring:
- How long will inspection take?
- What's included?
- Can I attend?
- When do I get the report?

If they can't answer clearly, move on.
